items.title: HTMLIFrameElement#loading is enabled in Safari TP

items.content_html:
This updates the firefox-specific WebMIDI secure access notes.

The story is a bit complex, but in essence:

  • From FF100 to FF106 (inclusive) WebMidi use was granted access by a site permission add-on that the web developer had to request from Mozilla and was installed by the user.
  • It is no longer possible to request that original site permission add on, but from FF107 the addon is automatically created by FF so it is not needed
  • In versions 100 to 104 you basically can't use WebMidi but in version 105 a permission was added to allow you to bypass the permission addon check.

The notes capture this. Note the preferences are not included as flags data because they don't bypass secure context, just the gating check. Very messy, but all of this will disappear when the WebMidi overarching flag gets enabled by default.

Note, I don't know how site permission now works really (i.e. I think understand what happens, just not why it has any real value as a security mechanism). That doesn't matter though because I've been informed that developers don't have to worry about this other than the information here.

This is all discussed in mdn/content#21951 (comment)

@queengooborg FYI.
items.title: Navigator.requestMIDIAccess - secure access gating changes

items.content_html:
Summary

The NavigateEvent interface has been updated in the spec, and Chrome. The changes are as follows:

  • canIntercept - see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5194055716700160. Added in Chrome 105
  • restoreScroll() - See https://chromestatus.com/feature/5029730789621760. replaced with scroll() in Chrome and spec. Needs deprecating/not standards track, removed in Chrome 108.
  • transitionWhile() - see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5169970311856128 and https://chromestatus.com/feature/5194055716700160. replaced with intercept() in Chrome and spec. Needs deprecating/not standards track, removed in Chrome 108.
  • canTransition - see above bugs for details. Needs deprecating/not standards track, removed in Chrome 108

Test results and supporting details

I have looked at the spec (https://wicg.github.io/navigation-api/#navigate-event-class), and confirmed the changes described above. I also looked through the Chrome source code and ran some demos, and confirmed the situation in the browser.

Related issues
items.title: Updating data for api.NavigateEvent

items.content_html: This is a follow-up to #17947. In that PR, Opera couldn't be set to mirror for a subfeature due to it being set to null in the parent feature. This PR sets all such statements to mirror from Chrome.
items.title: Set Opera to mirror for Content-Security-Policy headers

items.content_html:
I'm not 100% sure about this but I think it is probably the right thing to do.

BCD currently has a subfeature for word-spacing taking a percentage. The subfeature has only Firefox supporting it. All that is still true.

However in 2019 percentages were removed as a value for this property (https://www.w3.org/TR/2019/WD-css-text-3-20191113/#changes-2018-12-06), see also mdn/content#21861.

So it seemed better to remove the subfeature, since it's no longer specced behavior. We could I suppose add a note to the main feature, like "Firefox also supports percentage values", but I wasn't sure it is worth it.
items.title: Remove percentage subfeature from word-spacing property

items.content_html:
It supported it from the moment radial-gradient was unprefixed, not sure why it was marked as not supported. In fact, the relevant examples on the MDN page with at work fine in Safari.

This is the bug where support was added: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=67166
items.title: Fix Safari support for `at` in `radial-gradient`

items.content_html:
Summary

Corrected SameSite schemeful statuses for Chromium-based browsers.

Test results and supporting details

  • Enforcement rolled out to Chrome 88+ in an out-of-bounds manner
    • Reference: Chrome Platform Status
    • Chrome for Desktop, Chrome for Android
  • Flags in the Chromium source code were changed in 91
    • Reference: Diff between Chromium 90 and 91 (Search for 9b8d9f0)
  • Browsers based on Chromium 91
    • Edge 91
    • Opera 77: Release notes
    • Opera for Android 64: Release notes
    • Samsung Internet 16: Release notes

Related issues

A follow-up on #9352.
items.title: SameSite: Corrections on "schemeful" support status

Summary

Test results and supporting details

Notes

There seem to be some discrepancies in wording and metadata between the margin and padding properties (padding has version_removed, margin doesn't but has the version in the note text). I'm happy to fix that as well if you tell me which version is preferred.
items.title: Update version ranges for Safari snap scroll implementation bug

items.content_html:
Summary

These changes were generated procedurally by the mdn-bcd-collector project using data collected from the Meta Quest browser.

Test results and supporting details

This patch is reproducible using the mdn-bcd-collector project at revision 4c430c1bb8bc2fcd3f72778e1dbe62bbb565587b and the data submitted to mdn-bcd-results here: foolip/mdn-bcd-results#3278

Related issues

This is based on gh-17908 which has not been accepted at the time of submission. Although it may be technically possible to express this patch as an independent change set, the semantics of the "mirror" support value mean that there will be less churn if the Chrome for Android data is modified first. Feedback regarding the changes to Chrome for Android may be better shared in gh-17908.
items.title: Update support data for Meta Quest browser

items.content_html:
Summary

The changes in the first commit were generated procedurally by the mdn-bcd-collector project using data collected from Chrome for Android and following three corrections to its interpretation of the "mirror" support value:

foolip/mdn-bcd-collector#2326
foolip/mdn-bcd-collector#2297
foolip/mdn-bcd-collector#2280

Test results and supporting details

The modifications in the second commit were made manually.

The Chromium commit "Rename XR interface to XRSystem" was released in version 83:

https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/commit/d7a0292ca39f93d358b68ee703b0eb4fb4901022

The Chromium commit "Enable drag and drop on Android platform by default" was released in version 54:

https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2016/10/chrome-for-android-update.html

Related issues

The modifications in the third commit were made manually.

The mdn-bcd-collector tool has a deficiency which cause it to produce incorrect changes for the Notification constructor. See "Testing constructors with no arguments misses some ways of disabling constructors": foolip/mdn-bcd-collector#970
items.title: Update support data for Chrome Android
